elements.content: Hydrothermal reactions of Cu(SO4)·5H2O with pyridyl- and pyrazine-substituted tetrazoles provided a series of materials of the Cu(II)/imine-tetrazolate/SO4 2– class. [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1) (3-pyrHtet-O = 2-hydroxy-3-Hpyridyltetrazolate) is molecular and exhibits the common {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+ core. In addition, the pyridyl group of the ligand has been hydroxylated to the to the 2-hydroxy-3-Hpyridyltetrazole form. While the two-dimensional [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] (2) also contains the {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+, the 3-pyrtet ligands (3-pyridyltetrazolate) project outward from the cluster core to link to adjacent clusters in forming the network connectivity. The two-dimensional (Me2NH2)[Cu(2-pyrtet)(SO4)] (3) exhibits binuclear building units {Cu2(2-pyrtet)}2+ that link to adjacent units through the sulfato groups. In contrast, the pyrazinetetrazolate derivative, [Cu4(pyrztet)6(H2O)2(SO4)] (4), is constructed from {Cu4(tetrazolate)6(H2O)2(SO4)} n chains linked through the pyrazinetetrazolate ligands into a three-dimensional framework. The magnetic properties of the compounds reflect these structural characteristics.

The magnetic properties of the compounds reflect these structural characteristics.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reactions of Cu(SO4)·5H2O with imine-functionalized tetrazoles provide a series of materials of the general class Cu(II)/imine-tetrazolate/SO4 2−. The structure of the two-dimensional [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] is shown.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reactions of Cu(SO4)⋅5H2O with imine-functionalized tetrazoles provide a series of materials of the general class Cu(II)/imine-tetrazolate/SO4 2-. The structure of the two-dimensional [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] is shown.

elements.content: Solid state coordination chemistry focuses on the rational design of materials for technological applications based on molecular scale composites of inorganic and organic components. Such materials exhibit a vast compositional range and significant structural complexity that allow for applications in fields ranging from heavy construction to molecular electronics.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Solid state coordination chemistry focuses on the rational design of materials for technological applications based on molecular scale composites of inorganic and organic components. Such materials exhibit a vast compositional range and significant structural complexity that allow for applications in fields ranging from heavy construction to molecular electronics.

elements.content: Organic–inorganic hybrid compounds of this type include materials constructed from metal or metal cluster nodes linked through polyfunctional carboxylates, polypyridyl linkers, and organophosphonate ligands. Such materials have been extensively explored by Clearfield, Ferey, Kitagawa, Yaghi, and others.
elements.clean_text: Organic-inorganic hybrid compounds of this type include materials constructed from metal or metal cluster nodes linked through polyfunctional carboxylates, polypyridyl linkers, and organophosphonate ligands. Such materials have been extensively explored by Clearfield, Ferey, Kitagawa, Yaghi, and others.

elements.content: Another class of bridging ligands that have been exploited in the construction of complex organic–inorganic architectures are the polyazaheterocyclic compounds, of which 1,2,4-triazole and tetrazole are characteristic (Scheme ). These ligands exhibit not only the ability to bridge multiple metal sites to afford polynuclear and extended structures but also superexchange properties that provide unusual magnetic behavior and a facility of modification to allow introduction of additional functionality.

These ligands exhibit not only the ability to bridge multiple metal sites to afford polynuclear and extended structures but also superexchange properties that provide unusual magnetic behavior and a facility of modification to allow introduction of additional functionality.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gr7" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2012-00261k_0002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Our investigations have focused on the structural chemistry of metal-triazolate and metal-tetrazolate frameworks prepared by hydrothermal methods. In the course of these studies, we noted that the modified polyazaheterocyclic ligands 4-(4-pyridyl)pyrazolate and 4-pyridyltetrazolate in the N2,N3 bridging mode function as expanded analogues of 1,2,4-triazolate (Scheme ). This observation motivated us to examine the structural consequences of modification of the pyridyl nitrogen donor location and the substitution of a pyrazine group for the pyridyl substituent (Scheme ).

In the course of these studies, we noted that the modified polyazaheterocyclic ligands 4-(4-pyridyl)pyrazolate and 4-pyridyltetrazolate in the N2,N3 bridging mode function as expanded analogues of 1,2,4-triazolate (Scheme ). This observation motivated us to examine the structural consequences of modification of the pyridyl nitrogen donor location and the substitution of a pyrazine group for the pyridyl substituent (Scheme ).

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch3" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>3</label>
<graphic id="gr9" orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg-2012-00261k_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

We have also noted that introduction of coordinating anions in expanding from the metal/polyazaheterocyclic ligand system to the metal/polyazaheterocyclic ligand/anion system dramatically influences the structures and properties of the composite materials. The structural influences were most pronounced when the anion is sulfate. Encouraged by these results, we have investigated the hydrothermal and structural chemistry of copper(II) sulfate with 2- and 3-pyridyltetrazole and pyrazinetetrazole. We report the structures of the molecular [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1), the two-dimensional [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] (2) and (Me2NH2)[Cu(2-pyrtet)(SO4)] (3), and the three-dimensional [Cu4(pyrztet)6(H2O)2(SO4)] (4) (pyrHtet = pyridyltetrazole; pyrzHtet = pyrazinetetrazole).

The structural influences were most pronounced when the anion is sulfate. Encouraged by these results, we have investigated the hydrothermal and structural chemistry of copper(II) sulfate with 2- and 3-pyridyltetrazole and pyrazinetetrazole. We report the structures of the molecular [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1), the two-dimensional [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] (2) and (Me2NH2)[Cu(2-pyrtet)(SO4)] (3), and the three-dimensional [Cu4(pyrztet)6(H2O)2(SO4)] (4) (pyrHtet = pyridyltetrazole; pyrzHtet = pyrazinetetrazole).

elements.content: The ligands 2- and 3-pyridyltetrazole and pyrazinetetrazole were prepared by the “click” chemistry approach using zinc catalysis in aqueous solution or by the use of modified montmorillonite K-10. All other chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. Copper sulfate and hydrofluoric acid (99.5%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23 mL poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly, and the initial pH was measured before heating. Water was distilled above 3.0MX in-housing using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. The initial and final pH values of each reaction were measured using color pHast sticks. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Perkin–Elmer 1600 series FTIR spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

The ligands 2- and 3-pyridyltetrazole and pyrazinetetrazole were prepared by the "click" chemistry approach using zinc catalysis in aqueous solution or by the use of modified montmorillonite K-10. All other chemicals were used as obtained without further purification. Copper sulfate and hydrofluoric acid (99.5%) were purchased from Alfa Aesar. All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23 mL poly(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly, and the initial pH was measured before heating. Water was distilled above 3.0MX in-housing using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. The initial and final pH values of each reaction were measured using color pHast sticks. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 series FTIR spectrometer.

elements.content: Structural measurements were performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD diffractometer at low temperature (90 K) using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (Mo Kα = 0.71073 Å). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. After all of the nonhydrogen atoms had been located, the model was refined against F 2, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined isotropically. Neutral atom scattering coefficients and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables, Vol. C. All calculations were performed using SHELXTL crystallographic software packages.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Structural measurements were performed on a Bruker-AXS SMART-CCD diffractometer at low temperature (90 K) using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (Mo Kα = 0.71073 Å). The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption using SADABS. The structures were solved by direct methods. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. After all of the nonhydrogen atoms had been located, the model was refined against F 2, initially using isotropic and later anisotropic thermal displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined isotropically. Neutral atom scattering coefficients and anomalous dispersion corrections were taken from the International Tables, Vol. C. All calculations were performed using SHELXTL crystallographic software packages.

Darling, K.; Zubieta, J. Unpublished results.

Hydrothermal synthesis is an effective method for the preparation of X-ray quality single crystals of coordination polymers. In the temperature domain of conventional hydrothermal methods, the reactants are solubilized while retaining their structural features in the product phases. Hydrothermal reactions, typically carried out in the temperature range of 120–260 °C under autogenous pressure, exploit the self-assembly of the product from soluble precursors. The reduced viscosity of water under these conditions enhances diffusion processes so that solvent extraction of solids and crystal growth from solution is favored. Because problems associated with different solubilities of organic and inorganic starting materials are minimized, a variety of precursors may be introduced, as well as a number of organic and/or inorganic structure-directing or charge-balancing reagents from which those of appropriate size, shape, and charge may be selected for efficient crystal packing during the crystallization process. Under such nonequilibrium crystallization conditions, metastable kinetic phases rather than the thermodynamic phase may also be isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Hydrothermal synthesis is an effective method for the preparation of X-ray quality single crystals of coordination polymers. In the temperature domain of conventional hydrothermal methods, the reactants are solubilized while retaining their structural features in the product phases. Hydrothermal reactions, typically carried out in the temperature range of 120-260 °C under autogenous pressure, exploit the self-assembly of the product from soluble precursors. The reduced viscosity of water under these conditions enhances diffusion processes so that solvent extraction of solids and crystal growth from solution is favored. Because problems associated with different solubilities of organic and inorganic starting materials are minimized, a variety of precursors may be introduced, as well as a number of organic and/or inorganic structure-directing or charge-balancing reagents from which those of appropriate size, shape, and charge may be selected for efficient crystal packing during the crystallization process. Under such nonequilibrium crystallization conditions, metastable kinetic phases rather than the thermodynamic phase may also be isolated.

elements.content: While hydrothermal reactions generally retain the structural integrity of the ligand components, in situ modification of ligands is not uncommon. In the case of compound 1, the 3-pyridyltetrazole ligand has been hydroxylated at the α-carbon of the pyridine ring to form a covalent hydrate, presumably in a Gillard type reaction. Similarly, the synthesis of compound 3 produces the Me2NH2 + cation from the decomposition of the tetrazole fragment of ligands. The addition of Me2NH2 + to the reaction mixture significantly increases the product yield.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of compounds 1–4 exhibit bands in the 1000–1520 cm–1 range characteristic of υ(C–N), υ(N–N), and δ(NNN) of the tetrazolate ligand, while a persistent feature at 600–690 cm–1 may be attributed to a υ(S–O) band of the sulfate ligand.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the structure of [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1) is a neutral trinuclear molecular species. The compound contains the common {M3(μ3-OH)}5+ unit previously described for [M3(trz)3(OH)3(H2O)4] (M = Cu, Ni), [Cu3(OH)(trz)3][Cu2Br4], {[Cu3O(OH)(trz)2]3Cl2(H2C3N3O3)}, [Cu4(trz)3]OH, [Cu6 IICu2 I(trz)6(SO4)3(OH)2(H2O)], [Co3(OH)(SO4)(btt)(H2O)4], and [Fe3(OH)(Htrz)3(HSO4)(SO4)2] [trz = triazolate, btt = 5,5′,5″-(1,3,5-phenylene)tris(1H-tetrazole)]. The copper sites exhibit “4 + 2” Jahn–Teller distorted geometry with the equatorial plane defined by two nitrogen donors from two N1,N2-bridging tetrazolate ligands, the μ3-OH group and a hydroxyl oxygen of the hydroxy-pyridyl group of the ligand; the axial sites are occupied by a sulfate oxygen and an aqua ligand.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structures

As shown in Figure , the structure of [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1) is a neutral trinuclear molecular species. The compound contains the common {M3(μ3-OH)}5+ unit previously described for [M3(trz)3(OH)3(H2O)4] (M = Cu, Ni), [Cu3(OH)(trz)3][Cu2Br4], {[Cu3O(OH)(trz)2]3Cl2(H2C3N3O3)}, [Cu4(trz)3]OH, [Cu6 IICu2 I(trz)6(SO4)3(OH)2(H2O)], [Co3(OH)(SO4)(btt)(H2O)4], and [Fe3(OH)(Htrz)3(HSO4)(SO4)2] [trz = triazolate, btt = 5,5',5"-(1,3,5-phenylene)tris(1H-tetrazole)]. The copper sites exhibit "4 + 2" Jahn-Teller distorted geometry with the equatorial plane defined by two nitrogen donors from two N1,N2-bridging tetrazolate ligands, the μ3-OH group and a hydroxyl oxygen of the hydroxy-pyridyl group of the ligand; the axial sites are occupied by a sulfate oxygen and an aqua ligand.

elements.content: Mixed polyhedral and ball and stick representation of the structure of [Cu3(OH)(H2O)3(3-pyrHtet-O)3(SO4)] (1). Color scheme: copper, blue polyhedra; sulfur, yellow tetrahedra; oxygen, red spheres; nitrogen, light blue spheres; and carbon, black spheres. The color scheme is used throughout.

elements.content: Each hydroxypyridyltetrazolate ligand bridges two copper sites through N1,N2 donors and chelates to a site through additional coordination through the hydroxyl group. The sulfato ligand shares an oxygen vertex with each copper site, having the fourth oxygen uncoordinated and projecting toward a neighboring cluster.

elements.content: An unusual feature of the structure of 1 is the presence of the hydroxylated form of the ligand. The in situ hydroxylation of pyridine-based ligands in hydrothermal reactions in the presence of copper or molybdenum has been noted previously and appears to be a recurrent theme of the chemistry. The final difference Fourier map clearly reveals the pyridyl nitrogen as a protonation site. Consequently, the ligand is present as the singly negatively charged 2-hydroxy-3-Hpyridyl tetrazole, {N4C-C5NHO}−.

Consequently, the ligand is present as the singly negatively charged 2-hydroxy-3-Hpyridyl tetrazole, {N4C-C5NHO}-.

elements.content: The structure of the two-dimensional material [Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(3-pyrtet)2(SO4)] (2) is shown in Figure . The layer is constructed from trinuclear {Cu3(OH)2(H2O)3(SO4)}2+ clusters linked through the 3-pyrtet ligands in the ac plane. While the trinuclear cluster exhibits the common {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+ core also found in compound 1, the detailed structure is quite distinct. In contrast to the cluster of 1, which exhibits three six coordinate Cu sites corner-sharing at a single μ3-OH vertex, the cluster of 2 offers a pair of edge-sharing pseudo-octahedral sites and a square pyramid site corner-sharing at the μ3-OH group. Each “4 + 2” site exhibits an equatorial plane occupied by a tetrazolate nitrogen, a pyridyl nitrogen, the μ3-OH group, and a μ2-OH ligand, while the axial positions are defined by a sulfato oxygen and an aqua ligand. The “4 + 1” axially distorted site exhibits a basal plane occupied by two tetrazolate nitrogen donors, the μ3-OH group, and an aqua ligand; the apical site is defined by a sulfato oxygen.

elements.content: Each trinuclear unit is associated with four 3-pyrtet ligands. Two bridge through N2,N3 sites between a six coordinate and the five coordinate copper sites, while the other two employ pyridyl nitrogens bound to the six coordinate copper sites. The 3-pyrtet groups project outward from the trinuclear core and link each cluster to four adjacent clusters in the plane. The clusters are aligned in the plane such that the S–O vectors of the uncoordinated sulfato oxygens lie within the plane approximately parallel to the a-axis. As a result of this alignment, the aqua ligands of the five coordinate copper sites project into the interlamellar domains.

elements.content: While the structure of (Me2NH2)[Cu(2-pyrtet)(SO4)] (3) is also two-dimensional as shown in Figure , it does not share the common {M3(μ3-OH)}5+ motif. The secondary building unit in this case is a binuclear {Cu2(2-pyrtet)}2+ group, which is linked to four adjacent binuclear units through sulfato groups.

elements.content: The copper sites exhibit “4 + 1” square pyramidal geometry with the basal plane defined by the N1 and pyridyl nitrogens of a chelating 2-pyrtet ligand, the N2 donor of a second 2-pyrtet ligand, and a sulfato oxygen; the apical site is occupied by an oxygen from a second sulfato group. Each 2-pyrtet ligand bridges two copper sites through N1,N2 donors and chelates to one of these sites through the pyridyl donor. The location of the pyridyl nitrogen adjacent to the carbon 5 site favors the chelate bonding mode rather than the bridging mode between secondary building units.

The location of the pyridyl nitrogen adjacent to the carbon 5 site favors the chelate bonding mode rather than the bridging mode between secondary building units.

elements.content: Each sulfato group bridges two adjacent binuclear units, bonding to a basal site in one and an apical site in the second. Each sulfato group projects an uncoordinated oxygen into an intralamellar cavity and a second toward the interlamellar domains.

elements.content: The interlayer separation between the mean planes is ca. 12.5 Å. Because the 2-pyridyltetrazolate ligands are oriented normal to the planes, their projection into the interlamellar domain renders the packing of layers relatively dense. As a consequence, the Me2NH2 + cations nestle in the layers just above and below the 22 membered {−O–S–O–Cu–N–N–Cu–O–S–O–Cu}2 rings that fuse to form the core of the layer structure of 3.

elements.content: The structure of the pyrazine derivative [Cu4(pyrztet)6(H2O)2(SO4)] (4) is three-dimensional (Figure ). The structure consists of {Cu4(tetrazolate)6(H2O)2(SO4)} n chains, running approximately along the crystallographic c-axis, each linked through the pyrztet ligands to four adjacent chains to provide the three-dimensional expansion.

elements.content: The secondary building unit of the chain is the tetranuclear {Cu4(pyrztet)8(H2O)2(SO4)2} unit shown in Figure b. There are two distinct Cu(II) environments within the nonlinear tetranuclear unit. The interior pair of copper sites exhibits distorted {CuN6} geometry. Each of these copper sites participates in bonding to four pyrztet ligands. Two pyrztet ligands provide N1,N2 bridging between the copper centers to provide the common {Cu2(tet)2} coordination unit. In addition, these pyrztet ligands chelate to the central copper sites through a pyrazine nitrogen donor. These nitrogen donors adopt a meridional orientation about the copper sites. The remaining coordination sites are occupied by two tetrazolate nitrogen donors from pyrztet ligands that bridge each central copper center to a peripheral copper site through the common bis-N1,N2 tetrazolate motif. One of these pyrztet ligands chelates to the central copper site through a pyrazine nitrogen donor, while the second chelates to a peripheral copper center.
elements.clean_text: The secondary building unit of the chain is the tetranuclear {Cu4(pyrztet)8(H2O)2(SO4)2} unit shown in Figure b. There are two distinct Cu(II) environments within the nonlinear tetranuclear unit. The interior pair of copper sites exhibits distorted {CuN6} geometry. Each of these copper sites participates in bonding to four pyrztet ligands. Two pyrztet ligands provide N1,N2 bridging between the copper centers to provide the common {Cu2(tet)2} coordination unit. In addition, these pyrztet ligands chelate to the central copper sites through a pyrazine nitrogen donor. These nitrogen donors adopt a meridional orientation about the copper sites. The remaining coordination sites are occupied by two tetrazolate nitrogen donors from pyrztet ligands that bridge each central copper center to a peripheral copper site through the common bis-N1,N2 tetrazolate motif. One of these pyrztet ligands chelates to the central copper site through a pyrazine nitrogen donor, while the second chelates to a peripheral copper center.

elements.content: The peripheral copper sites exhibit distorted {CuN4O2} geometry. This coordination is defined by two tetrazolate donors from the bis-N1,N2 pyrztet ligands and the pyrazine nitrogen of the chelating pyrztet in a meridional arrangement, while the remaining coordination sites are occupied by an aqua ligand, a sulfato oxygen donor, and a pyrazine nitrogen donor from a pyrztet ligand directed toward an adjacent chain. The copper sites of compound 4 do not exhibit the pronounced Jahn–Teller induced “4 + 2” axial distortion observed for compounds 1–3.

The copper sites of compound 4 do not exhibit the pronounced Jahn-Teller induced "4 + 2" axial distortion observed for compounds 1-3.

elements.content: The sulfato ligands bridge adjacent tetranuclear clusters of the chain through O,O′-bridging coordination. Each sulfato ligand consequently exhibits two uncoordinated oxygen atoms, projecting between tetranuclear building units.

elements.content: The triangular {M3(μ3-OH)} core of complexes 1 and 2 is a recurrent theme of the structural chemistry of Cu(II) and other transition metal. The {M3(μ3-OH)} and {M3(μ3-O)} cores have been described for systems with peripheral ligands such as pyrazole and triazole and homo- and heterometallic examples include {Cu(II)3}, {V(IV)3}, {Cr(III)3}, {Co(II)3)}, {Fe(III)3}, {Ni(III)3}, and {Cr(III)2Fe(III)}.
elements.clean_text:
The {M3(μ3-O(H)} Cores

The triangular {M3(μ3-OH)} core of complexes 1 and 2 is a recurrent theme of the structural chemistry of Cu(II) and other transition metal. The {M3(μ3-OH)} and {M3(μ3-O)} cores have been described for systems with peripheral ligands such as pyrazole and triazole and homo- and heterometallic examples include {Cu(II)3}, {V(IV)3}, {Cr(III)3}, {Co(II)3)}, {Fe(III)3}, {Ni(III)3}, and {Cr(III)2Fe(III)}.

elements.content: In the specific instances of azolate N,N′-bridging ligand types about the {M3(μ3-O(OH)} core, a variety of additional peripheral or capping ligands may be accommodated, as shown in Figure . Furthermore, there is considerable variability of the M–O bond distances within the triad. Potentially bridging coligands such as capping sulfato- or phosphato-groups can also provide spatial expansion to generate extended architectures. The number and diversity of compounds featuring these triangulo cores reflect the versatility of the unit in accommodating bridging and other peripheral ligands.

(d) The {M3(μ3-O)} cluster with two additional doubly bridging N1 and N2 azolates. (e) Incorporation of sulfate anion as an additional bridging ligand to the trinuclear core. (f) Sulfate as a capping anion to the {M3(μ3-OH)} structural motif. (g) The structural building unit of compound 1 of this study. (h) {M3(μ3-O)} cluster variant with phosphate as a capping ligand with the fourth oxo group of the phosphate anion providing extension of the cluster motif into a chain structure.

(e) Incorporation of sulfate anion as an additional bridging ligand to the trinuclear core. (f) Sulfate as a capping anion to the {M3(μ3-OH)} structural motif. (g) The structural building unit of compound 1 of this study. (h) {M3(μ3-O)} cluster variant with phosphate as a capping ligand with the fourth oxo group of the phosphate anion providing extension of the cluster motif into a chain structure.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2 have been studied, and the results are presented. Compounds 3 and 4 were not subjected to magnetic measurements due to the fact that they are contaminated with paramagnetic impurities and no satisfactory purification scheme could be developed despite numerous attempts.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetism

The magnetic properties of compounds 1 and 2 have been studied, and the results are presented. Compounds 3 and 4 were not subjected to magnetic measurements due to the fact that they are contaminated with paramagnetic impurities and no satisfactory purification scheme could be developed despite numerous attempts.

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of the {Cu3(μ3-O(H)} core has been extensively studied with a comprehensive review of the field being provided by Ferrer et al. The compounds were found to exhibit strong antiferromagnetic and, in most cases, antisymmetric exchange. The unit cells of compounds 1 and 2 consist of a Cu(II) triangle as the dominant magnetic unit. The values for χT at 300 K are 0.82 and 0.88 emu mol–1 K per trimer for compounds 1 and 2, respectively. These numbers are less than the expected values for three Cu(II) ions (3χCu T = 1.125 cm3 mol–1 K, S = 1/2) (Figure ). The χT values decrease in a continuous fashion from room temperature and reach a plateau at ∼60 K and finally decrease to 0.21 and 0.37 emu mol–1 K at 2 K. The temperature dependence of 1/χ between 300 and 60 K approximates Curie–Weiss behavior with C = 1.37 emu mol–1 K, θ = −200 K and C = 1.45 emu mol–1 K, θ = −190 K for compounds 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S7 and S8in the ). These values indicate antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) centers. As a first approximation, it is often assumed that the three metal ions are essentially structurally equivalent, such that J = J 1 = J 2 = J 3 and g = g 1 = g 2 = g 3 and the spin Hamiltonian H iso = –J(S 1 × S 2 + S 2 × S 3 + S 1 × S 3) can be used to describe the magnetic interactions. An attempt to use this approach, however, failed to reproduce the low-temperature decrease in χT. Different J and g values for the different magnetic centers do not improve the fit and lead to overparameterization.

elements.content: Another approach was used assuming a strong contribution of antisymmetric exchange. For fitting experimental data of compounds 1 and 2, we used the Hamiltonian: H = H iso + H ASE + H Zeem H iso = − J ( S 1 S 2 + S 2 S 3 ) − j S 1 S 3 H AS = G Z [ S 1 × S 2 + S 2 × S 3 + S 3 × S 1 ] H Zeem = g ∥ β ( S 1 Z + S 2 Z + S 3 Z ) H Z + g ⊥ β [ ( S 1 X + S 2 X + S 3 X ) H X + ( S 1 Y + S 2 Y + S 3 Y ) H Y where H iso is a Hamiltonian for isotropic exchange for an isosceles triangle with parameters J = J 12 = J 23 and j = J 13; H AS is an axial Hamiltonian for antisymmetric exchange with G Z parallel to the C 3 axis and G ⊥ = 0; H Zeem is an axial Hamiltonian for the Zeeman interaction with g ∥ = g 1z = g 2z = g 3z and g ⊥ = g 1x = g 2x = g 3x = g 1y = g 2y = g 3y . The exact analytical expression for the magnetic susceptibility χ can be found in the article by Ferrer and co-workers.

elements.content: The magnetic data were fitted over the entire temperature range of 2–300 K with the parameters J = −184.2 cm–1, j = −171 cm–1, G Z = 19.9 cm–1, g ∥ = 2.35, and g ⊥ = 2.14 for compound 1 and J = −140.8 cm–1, j = −109.6 cm–1, G Z = 8.8 cm–1, g ∥ = 2.28, and g ⊥ = 2.03 for compound 2. All of the derived values are in good agreement to those reported for similar compounds. The difference between J and j for compound 2 is much larger than that for compound 1 because of the large difference in the Cu–O–Cu angles of compound 2. A symmetrical magnetic core of compound 1 with Cu–O–Cu angle θ = 115° gives a predictable magnetic exchange parameter J. Using the empirical formula J = −13.65θ + 1385 from reference , the magnetic exchange parameter was estimated to be J = −186.75 cm–1.

Using the empirical formula J = -13.65θ + 1385 from reference , the magnetic exchange parameter was estimated to be J = -186.75 cm-1.

elements.content: It is instructive to note that weak ferromagnets (canted antiferromagnetic materials) are one of the major classes of magnetically ordered materials. The origin of the spin canting is the presence of Dzyaloshinsky–Moriya antisymmetric magnetic interactions. However, the antisymmetric exchange parameter G is generally very small and can be observed only at low temperature. Even then, in most cases, it is masked by much stronger isotropic magnetic exchange or by magnetic ordering. Complexes with the trinuclear {Cu3(μ3-OH)} core are unique systems for which antisymmetric interactions are strong enough to be observed at relatively high temperature, since the value of the G parameter is comparable to the isotropic exchange parameter J. Consequently, complexes exhibiting the trinuclear {Cu3(μ3-OH)} core allow analysis of magnetic susceptibility data and independent fitting of the magnetic parameters. While reasonable fits to the magnetic parameters have been reported for a limited number of materials containing this structural triad, the observed magnetic behavior is frequently irreproducible due to the lability of the {Cu3(μ3-OH)} magnetic core.
elements.clean_text: It is instructive to note that weak ferromagnets (canted antiferromagnetic materials) are one of the major classes of magnetically ordered materials. The origin of the spin canting is the presence of Dzyaloshinsky-Moriya antisymmetric magnetic interactions. However, the antisymmetric exchange parameter G is generally very small and can be observed only at low temperature. Even then, in most cases, it is masked by much stronger isotropic magnetic exchange or by magnetic ordering. Complexes with the trinuclear {Cu3(μ3-OH)} core are unique systems for which antisymmetric interactions are strong enough to be observed at relatively high temperature, since the value of the G parameter is comparable to the isotropic exchange parameter J. Consequently, complexes exhibiting the trinuclear {Cu3(μ3-OH)} core allow analysis of magnetic susceptibility data and independent fitting of the magnetic parameters. While reasonable fits to the magnetic parameters have been reported for a limited number of materials containing this structural triad, the observed magnetic behavior is frequently irreproducible due to the lability of the {Cu3(μ3-OH)} magnetic core.

elements.content: Hydrothermal methods have been used to prepare a series of crystalline materials of the general type Cu(II)/substituted tetrazole/SO4 2–. The structural chemistry reflects the coordination preferences of the substituted tetrazole ligand: 3-pyridyltetrazole bridges metal or metal cluster nodes, 2-pyridyltetrazole adopts a chelating modality through a tetrazole nitrogen and a pyridyl nitrogen, and pyrazine tetrazole adopts both chelating and bridging roles.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Hydrothermal methods have been used to prepare a series of crystalline materials of the general type Cu(II)/substituted tetrazole/SO4 2-. The structural chemistry reflects the coordination preferences of the substituted tetrazole ligand: 3-pyridyltetrazole bridges metal or metal cluster nodes, 2-pyridyltetrazole adopts a chelating modality through a tetrazole nitrogen and a pyridyl nitrogen, and pyrazine tetrazole adopts both chelating and bridging roles.

elements.content: A recurrent theme of the extended structures of such materials is the presence of embedded copper(II)/tetrazolate clusters as architectural motifs. Thus, the structures of 1 and 2 exhibit the common {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+ trinuclear secondary building block, while the structures of 3 and 4 exhibit the persistent {Cu2(μ2-tetrazolate)2} building block.

Thus, the structures of 1 and 2 exhibit the common {Cu3(μ3-OH)}5+ trinuclear secondary building block, while the structures of 3 and 4 exhibit the persistent {Cu2(μ2-tetrazolate)2} building block.

elements.content: It is also noteworthy that hydrothermal conditions promoted in situ ligand reactions leading to the hydroxylation of 3-pyridyltetrazole in compound 1 and to ligand decomposition in 3 to provide Me2NH2 + cations.
elements.clean_text: It is also noteworthy that hydrothermal conditions promoted in situ ligand reactions leading to the hydroxylation of 3-pyridyltetrazole in compound 1 and to ligand decomposition in 3 to provide Me2NH2 + cations.

elements.content: The structural variety and range of magnetic properties of the phases of this study suggest that a rich magneto-structural chemistry can be developed for compounds of the general type M(II)/substituted tetrazole/anion where M(II) = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu and the anion is NO3 –, SO4 2–, PO4 3–, MoO4 2–, VO3 –, or ReO4 –. However, while the predictable incorporation of specific building blocks into tailored materials will lead to the discovery of new classes of hybrid compounds with novel structures and compositions, the design principles remain elusive. The complex structures of this study result from the large amount of framework required to accommodate the organic components and the ordering of inorganic substructures within the framework. In other words, it is the subtle interplay of hydrophobic/hydrophilic interactions, inherent in the combination of organic and inorganic subunits, which dictate nucleation and crystal growth. Such controlled linkage of molecular building blocks into solid state materials is a manifestation of self-assembly in supramolecular chemistry. Because only a small region of the vast parameter space of such materials has been surveyed, our understanding of the synthetic conditions required to prepare these materials by design remains rudimentary. Consequently, a great deal of effort has been expended by many investigators in defining those synthetic parameters that yield useful compositions and in characterizing the numerous structural prototypes that are isolated. Beyond this discovery phase, it is evident that primitive design principles have begun to emerge, particularly in the exploitation of conditions that produce recurring secondary building units.

A mixture of Cu(SO4)·5H2O (171 mg, 0.684 mmol), 5-(3-pyridyl)tetrazole (50 mg, 0.342 mmol), HF (400 μL), and H2O (10.00 g, 556 mmol) in a mole ratio of 2.00:1.00:0.58:1626 was stirred briefly before heating to 200 °C for 48 h (initial and final pH values of 1.1 and 1.0, respectively). Dark green block crystals of 1, suitable for X-ray diffraction, were isolated in 50% yield. Anal. calcd for C18H19Cu3N15O11S: C, 25.6; H, 2.25; N, 24.9. Found: C, 25.2; H, 2.17; N, 24.8. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3415(b), 1428(m), 1144(m), 1095(s), 1062(s), 1018(m), 973(m) 819(w), 698(m).

A mixture of Cu(SO4)·5H2O (171 mg, 0.684 mmol), 5-(3-pyridyl)tetrazole (50 mg, 0.342 mmol), and H2O (10.00 g, 556 mmol) in a mole ratio of 2.00:1.00:1626 was stirred briefly before heating to 135 °C for 48 h (initial and final pH values of 2.5 and 2.3, respectively). Dark blue block crystals of 2, suitable for X-ray diffraction, were isolated in 80% yield. Anal. calcd for C12H16Cu3N10O9S: C, 21.6; H, 2.40; N, 21.0. Found: C, 21.7; H, 2.55; N, 20.8. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3481(b), 3086(w), 2924(w), 1602(s), 1571(s), 1514(m), 1162(m), 1095(m), 1054(m), 618(w).

Synthesis of [Me<sub>2</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>] [Cu(2-pyrtet)(SO<sub>4</sub>)] (<bold>3</bold>)

The reaction of a solution of Cu(SO4)·5H2O (183 mg, 0.732 mmol), 5-(2-pyridyl)tetrazole (55 mg, 0.377 mmol), dimethylammonium chloride (31 mg, 0.380 mmol), and H2O (10.00 g, 556 mmol) in a mole ratio of 2.00:1.00:1.00:1475 at 120 °C for 64 h (initial and final pH values of 3.0 and 3.5, respectively) provided blue crystals of 3 in 55% yield. Synthesis of [Cu<sub>4</sub>(pyrztet)<sub>6</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)] (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of Cu(SO4)·5H2O (171 mg, 0.684 mmol), 2-tetrazole 5-yl pyrazine (52 mg, 0.342 mmol), and H2O (10.00 g, 556 mmol) in a mole ratio of 2.00:1.00:1626 was stirred briefly before heating to 135 °C for 48 h (initial and final pH values of 2.5 and 2.3, respectively). Dark blue block crystals of 4, suitable for X-ray diffraction, were isolated in 10% yield. Anal. calcd for C30H22Cu4N36O6S; C, 28.4; H, 1.73; N, 39.7. Found: C, 28.2; H, 1.89; N, 39.6. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3340(b), 1617(s) 1472(s), 1403(m), 1262(m), 1134(m), 802(s), 730(m), 597(m).

cln_elements.content: Common azolate bridged triads. (a and b) The prototypical {M3(μ3-O)} and {M3(μ3–OH)} cluster types. (c) A variant of the {M3(μ3-O)} cluster featuring a peripheral μ2-oxo group. (d) The {M3(μ3-O)} cluster with two additional doubly bridging N1 and N2 azolates. (e) Incorporation of sulfate anion as an additional bridging ligand to the trinuclear core. (f) Sulfate as a capping anion to the {M3(μ3-OH)} structural motif. (g) The structural building unit of compound 1 of this study. (h) {M3(μ3-O)} cluster variant with phosphate as a capping ligand with the fourth oxo group of the phosphate anion providing extension of the cluster motif into a chain structure.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Common azolate bridged triads. (a and b) The prototypical {M3(μ3-O)} and {M3(μ3-OH)} cluster types. (c) A variant of the {M3(μ3-O)} cluster featuring a peripheral μ2-oxo group. (d) The {M3(μ3-O)} cluster with two additional doubly bridging N1 and N2 azolates. (e) Incorporation of sulfate anion as an additional bridging ligand to the trinuclear core. (f) Sulfate as a capping anion to the {M3(μ3-OH)} structural motif. (g) The structural building unit of compound 1 of this study. (h) {M3(μ3-O)} cluster variant with phosphate as a capping ligand with the fourth oxo group of the phosphate anion providing extension of the cluster motif into a chain structure.
